node.title: White House previews Biden's economic message ahead of State of the Union
node.description: President Biden will reintroduce pieces of his domestic policy agenda when he addresses Congress during his State of the Union speech.

node.title: Ukraine's military, politicians targeted in hacking campaign - Facebook owner
node.description: Meta Platforms says a hacking group used Facebook to target a handful of public figures in Ukraine, including prominent military officials, politicians and a journalist.

node.title: Nelson homicide: Man charged with murder of Lake Takimoana
node.description: Police have charged a 30-year-old man with the murder of Lake Takimoana.

node.title: For Ukrainians, home is no longer safe. But some are staying.
node.description: "I have a big family. My kids want to stay home. They take music classes, they play chess, they speak English," said Mariya Kaprinska. "We are happy in our homeland, we don't want to leave anywhere."

node.title: How RATs changed the Covid-19 testing game
node.description: The Detail - The shift away from more sensitive PCR tests to rapid antigen tests as Omicron cases surge marks a significant change in New Zealand's Covid-19 strategy.

node.title: 'Very ill-conceived': Surf lifesavers frustrated over Covid-positive swimmer's rescue
node.description: A man with Covid-19 had to be rescued after he got into trouble at Auckland's Bethells Beach yesterday. Audio

node.title: Child abuse victim only latest to be failed by Fire and Emergency - advocate
node.description: A child who was sexually abused by a volunteer firefighter is only the latest of many to be let down by Fire and Emergency's complaints process, an advocate says.

node.title: 'Need a clothes peg on your nose': What stinks in Rotorua?
node.description: Lake weed on a $40 million lakefront redevelopment is causing a stench in Rotorua and has so far cost ratepayers about $20,000 to clear.

node.title: The Met Opera to stop working with artists who have ties to Putin
node.description: The Met vowed to cut ties with artists or institutions that support Putin "until the invasion and killing has been stopped, order has been restored, and restitutions have been made."

node.title: What to know about Volodymyr Zelensky
node.description: From "Dancing with the Stars" and playing a president on TV to becoming Ukraine's wartime president — here's what you need to know about Zelensky.

node.title: World's largest cargo plane destroyed by Russian strikes in Ukraine
node.description: "Russia may have destroyed our 'Mriya'. But they will never be able to destroy our dream of a strong, free and democratic European state," Ukraine's foreign minister tweeted.

node.title: Lt. Col. Vindman: West must not bend to Putin's "nuclear saber-rattling"
node.description: The Russia expert tells "CBS Mornings" that the Russian president is facing opposition from the West unlike anything he's faced before, but adds that "He's not a madman. He's not suicidal."

node.title: Musk activates free Starlink internet service in Ukraine
node.description: SpaceX CEO responded to a plea from a senior government official to extend the space-based internet service to Ukraine.

node.title: Olympic champion signals 'big announcement'
node.description: Two-time Olympic shot put champion Dame Valerie Adams is expected to announce retirement from international competition.

node.title: Four more people arrested at anti-mandate protest
node.description: Four people have been arrested at the anti-mandate protest on Parliament grounds since yesterday, including one man who has been charged with possessing an offensive weapon, police say.

node.title: Business confidence slumps amid Omicron, rising costs
node.description: The retail sector had the biggest slide in sentiment, while firms generally cut their expectations of profits, exports, employment, and investment.

node.title: Self-isolation for vaccinated travellers scrapped; arrival date for NZers outside Aust brought forward
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says from 11.59pm on 2 March vaccinated travellers will no longer need to self-isolate. Audio

node.title: NZers most in need bearing brunt of Omicron outbreak
node.description: New Zealanders who can least afford it are bearing the brunt of the Omicron outbreak - with isolation proving to be expensive or impossible for some. Audio

node.title: Ukrainian girl celebrates 3rd birthday as war rages outside
node.description: "I'm afraid to go for a walk with her, I forbid her to go up to the windows and turn on the light at night," a mother in Kharkiv said.

node.title: Derek Jeter announces surprise departure from Miami Marlins
node.description: Jeter became CEO of the Marlins in September 2017 when Bruce Sherman bought the team from Jeffrey Loria.

node.title: Thousands of protesters arrested in Russia as sanctions take toll
node.description: Observers say more than 5,000 demonstrators have been arrested in Russia since President Vladimir Putin ordered troops to invade Ukraine last week.

node.title: Countless human remains found at cartel "extermination site" in Mexico
node.description: Each day, technicians place what they find -- bones, buttons, earrings, scraps of clothing -- in paper bags labeled with their contents.

node.title: McLaughlin wins first IndyCar race
node.description: New Zealand driver Scott McLaughlin has won his first IndyCar race.

node.title: Estée Lauder fires senior exec for offensive Instagram post
node.description: The firing comes after John Demsey shared a meme on social media that included a racial slur.

node.title: Recap: Europe and Canada move to close skies to Russian planes
node.description: European nations and Canada have shut their airspace to Russian aircraft, an unprecedented step aimed at pressuring President Vladimir Putin to end his invasion of Ukraine.

node.title: Jackson to meet with lawmakers to begin Supreme Court confirmation process
node.description: Jackson's meetings with Schumer, McConnell, Durbin and Grassley will all be in person, the White House said.

node.title: White Ferns in confident mood going into World Cup
node.description: White Ferns coach Bob Carter says their drought-breaking series win over India gives them valuable confidence as the start of the World Cup in New Zealand looms.

node.title: Another flooding death in Queensland, with more wet weather to come
node.description: Heavy rains on Australia's east coast led to flooding, strandings, regional evacuations and deaths, with authorities warning of further life-threatening floods.

node.title: Target raises its minimum wage to as much as $24 an hour
node.description: Worker shortages around the U.S. during the pandemic have forced retailers to boost their pay.

node.title: More than 200,000 Ukrainians flee to Poland to escape Putin's attack
node.description: CBS News finds people shocked at the scale of Russia's attack on their country waiting for days with kids and pets in tow to cross the border.
